content: Click the 3-bar menu icon, upper right corner, New Account, Calendar, On the network, enter the icloud account, and https://caldav.icloud.com/ for the Location. Enter an app-specific password (generated at icloud) when asked for a password.
creator: sfhowes

content: The app-specific password is the key to adding an iCloud calendar to T-Bird. Do not use your normal logon ID and password to iCloud. Go to https://support.apple.com/en-us/102654 or use a search engine to look for the step by step approach to get the app-specific password.
creator: jimcandela

content: delete
creator: PavelkoT

content:
Hello bryan68,

Thanks for posting in the community forum.

Please try the following: If it is running, close Thunderbird. Next, delete the msf file in the Mail folder, which is a few levels below the Thunderbird program folder. After that, start Thunderbird and check if the same symptoms appear. (If you delete the msf file, nothing will be displayed immediately after startup, but the email contents should appear after a few minutes.)

I hope that solves the problem.
creator: Hisayuki.Fukuda

content: Thank you Hisayuki. That solved the problem in one folder (of which I have probably 100!). But now I know how to trigger rebuilding of the msf file when content is not there. Your reaching out makes me happy that I contribute and support Mozilla. have a great day
creator: bryan68

content: See https://www.thunderbird.net/donate/help/ for help or changes with donations. The page says there is a backlog in donor inquires at moment.

Hello Brian,

My guess is that you've never successfully received a single email from that Gmail account in Thunderbird? Maybe the problem is not with Thunderbird, but with the Gmail settings. You can try logging in to Gmail and checking if POP access is enabled in the settings.

I hope that solves the problem.

creator: max165

content: Please keep in mind that customer support is free, as is thunderbird. Very few people donate to support this, and many who do believe that a once-in-a-lifetime donation of $10 is 'support.' For that reason, support is just this forum. Further, most problems have nothing to do with Thunderbird, but are related to users needing help in figuring our their own account preferences. Okay, now that I've stated that, it appears that your problem may lie with the password. My suggestion is to remove whatever password is already there with these steps: - click to settings>privacy&security - click savedpasswords and showpasswords - then highlight rows for the account and delete them - at this point, thunderbird has no password for the account, so when you next request messages, thunderbird will prompt for it.
creator: davidsk

content:
max165 said
for a phone number or an email support number for Thunderbird / Mozilla and cannot find one anywhere, the customer service is appalling - do you have an email support you can give me? If so that would be great. Thanks

Mozilla/Thunderbird does not provide an email service. Thunderbird connects to email service only. Contact to your email box provider support. Got it?

content: Please visit Help > Troubleshooting Information > Show update history. Please screen shot what you see there.

content:
I have made some progress since I posted. I did successfully "downgrade" and I'm now running 128.5.0esr. However, I still would like to solve why a beta version was installed on my computer. This is the second time this happened - the first was on Oct 22nd. When I was on the beta version (133.0), the history showed no history. Now that I am on an esr version, the history, as shown in the image below, just shows the esr updates. It doesn't show the mysterious beta updates that happened on 10/22 and 11/27. I somehow seem to be on two update channels, both the esr and the beta. Do you know how I can get off of the beta permanently?

Thanks.
creator: Lynn.Kistler

content:
> I somehow seem to be on two update channels, both the esr and the beta.

Not according to your screen shot. And if Help > Troubleshooting Information shows you are on the esr channel, then it doesn't look from our perspective that Thunderbird has or could have moved you to another channel.

Also, if you have difficulty in the future, check Help > Troubleshooting Information to see the channel and version - you could have been on either "release" or "beta". I suspect you had gotten release.
creator: wsmwk

content: When I had the beta version running, it said "release" instead of "esr update channel". So it was "release" 133.0. Any idea how I can stop this from happening?
creator: Lynn.Kistler

content: I think I have a clue about this. My university does control some updates on my machine. I asked them specifically about Thunderbird, and they said no, they don't push Thunderbird updates, but they do push Firefox updates. I checked the dates, and the dates that I get the Thunderbird "release" (not esr) updates correspond with the Firefox release dates. Could these updates be linked, so that my Thunderbird also gets updated, even though the university doesn't realize it? Can this be controlled in some way? As always, thanks for your help!
creator: Lynn.Kistler

content:
• Start Windows in safe mode with networking enabled - https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode
  • Still In Windows safe mode, start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode - https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

Does problem change? (many users have found antivirus software causing problems)
